author: Liam Dempsey
tags: moriarty the patriot
body_content:
Ryosuke Takeuchi and Hikaru Miyoshi's Moriarty the Patriot series is taking to the stage once more for its fourth musical adaptation, and the mystery of how it's going to look is now a little bit clearer thanks to the release of character visuals for its twelve central characters, as follows:

 

Shogo Suzuki as

William James Moriarty

 

Ryo Hirano as

Sherlock Holmes

 

Hidetoshi Kubota as

Albert James Moriarty

 

Ikkei Yamamoto as

Louis James Moriarty

 

Yuki Izawa as

Sebastian Moran

 

Ryoki Nagae as

Fred Porlock

 

Kenta Kamakari as

John H. Watson

 

Kanon Nanaki as

Miss Hudson

 

Shun Takagi as

George Lestrade

 

Kazuma Kawahara as

Adam Whiteley

 

Yuka Yamauchi as

Mary Morstan

 

Rei Fujita as

Charles Augustus Milverton

 

As previously reported, the new musical will continue the story of the three Moriarty brothers, as they use their wits and influence to exact justice for Victorian London's lower classes. The play is scheduled to run January 27-29, 2023 at Osaka Shin-Kabukiza Theatre, and February 2-12, 2023 at Tokyo's Tennozu Galaxy Theater.

 

 

RELATED: Love Live! Takes to the Stage in First Ever School Idol Musical

 

 

If you're a fan of historical mysteries, check out the anime adaptation of Moriarty the Patriot in a range of subs and dubs, right here on Crunchyroll!

 

In the late 19th century, the British Empire nobility reigns while its working class suffers at their hands. Sympathetic to their plight, William James Moriarty wants to topple it all. Frustrated by the systemic inequity, Moriarty strategizes to fix the entire nation. Not even consulting detective Sherlock Holmes can stand in his way. It's time for crime to revolutionize the world!

 

Source: Comic Natalie

 

 

Der shy man behind @Shymander, Liam is a timezone-fluid Aussie with a distinct fondness for anime, Eurovision and creating odd stats projects despite hating math.

heading: Kaguya-sama Author Aka Akasaka Announces Retirement as Manga Illustrator
sub_heading: He will concentrate on story writing for manga works
metadata: One day after the final 271st chapter of his long-running Kaguya-sama: Love Is War manga was published in Japan, the manga's author Aka Akasaka announced his retirement as
author: Mikikazu Komatsu
tags: aka akasaka, kaguya-sama: love is war
body_content:
One day after the final 271st chapter of his long-running Kaguya-sama: Love Is War manga was published in Japan, the manga's author Aka Akasaka announced his retirement as a manga artist who draws on his official Twitter. The manga was first serialized in Shueisha's Miracle Jump from May 2015 to January 2016, then moved to the publisher's Weekly Young Jump and ran from March 2016 to November 2022.

 

RELATED: Kaguya-sama: Love is War Manga Ends With Official Enako Cosplay Photoshoot 

 

First, he thanks those who supported his seven-and-a-half year long serialization, "I had a lot of happy memories and I can look back now and wonder if I was able to make the people around me happy."

 

Then he states, "As for my future activities, I am planning to retire from working as a manga artist after this series. 'Retirement' means that I am going to retire from being a manga artist who draws, and I would like to concentrate on creating stories from now on. I want to continue my activities as a story writer. As for drawing, I intend to continue it loosely as a hobby."

 

He has already worked on Mengo Yokoyari-illustrated manga series Oshi no Ko as story writer since April 2020. From his statements, it is assumed that he will be concentrating on similar activities in the future.

 

As for Kaguya-sama, "Even though it has ended, there is still a big hint left in it," he said, "I am working hard to deliver it to you in the best possible way. I will try not to make it a superfluous story, so I hope you can look forward to it for a little while longer."

 

 

 

 

Source: Aka Akasaka official Twitter

 

©Aka Akasaka/SHUEISHA

heading: Yowamushi Pedal Limit Break Joins the Pack with Opening and Ending Theme Song Videos
sub_heading: Crunchyroll is currently simulcasting the sequel series
metadata: Cycling is all about pacing yourself correctly, so the latest exciting season of Yowamushi Pedal took its time and has now caught up to the Fall 2022 pack in releasing creditless opening
author: Liam Dempsey
tags: yowamushi pedal, yowamushi pedal limit break, 04 limited sazabys, novelbright, tms entertainment, fall 2022
body_content:
Cycling is all about pacing yourself correctly, so the latest exciting season of Yowamushi Pedal took its time and has now caught up to the Fall 2022 pack in releasing creditless opening and ending theme song videos, which you can watch from the official TOHO animation YouTube channel below.

 

Opening Theme

"Keep going" by 04 Limited Sazabys (RADIANT OP)

 

Ending Theme

"PRIDE" by Novelbright (Salaryman's Club OP)

 

 

RELATED: Challenge Yourself to a 5-Course Bike Rally Sponsored by Yowamushi Pedal

 

 

Based on the manga by Wataru Watanabe, Yowamushi Pedal Limit Break is directed by Osamu Nabeshima (D.Gray-man) at studio TMS Entertainment, with scripts by Kurasumi Sunayama (86 EIGHTY-SIX) and character designs by Yukiko Ban (Fruits Basket chief animation director).

 

If you're a fan of blood-pumping sports anime, check out the previous two seasons or the currently airing fifth of Yowamushi Pedal, right here on Crunchyroll!

 

With the team's combined strength, the Sohoku High bicycle racing club beat reigning champions Hakone Academy at the Interhigh national race and achieved an impressive overall victory. Now that their hot summer has ended and third-years Kinjou, Makishima, and Tadokoro have retired from the team, first-year participants in the Interhigh Onoda Sakamichi, Imaizumi Shunsuke, and Naruko Shoukichi, along with their new captain second-year Teshima Junta and vice-captain Aoyagi Hajime begin preparing as a "new team" for their second consecutive championship at the next Interhigh.

 

Source: Official Twitter (1,2)

 

 

Der shy man behind @Shymander, Liam is a timezone-fluid Aussie with a distinct fondness for anime, Eurovision and creating odd stats projects despite hating math.

heading: Gudetama: An Eggcellent Adventure Series Eggs on Shunsuke Takeuchi as 24 Characters
sub_heading: New key art and trailer released ahead of December 13 premiere
metadata: As the voice actor behind Takeda in My Senpai is Annoying and Brawler in Akudama Drive, we already knew that Shunsuke Takeuchi is a good egg — except now he'll be taking that
author: Liam Dempsey
tags: netflix, gudetama, gudetama: an eggcellent adventure, shunsuke takeuchi, 2022
body_content:
As the voice actor behind Takeda in My Senpai is Annoying and Brawler in Akudama Drive, we already knew that Shunsuke Takeuchi is a good egg — except now he'll be taking that on a literal sense as 24 different characters in upcoming Netflix CG-live-action series Gudetama: An Eggcellent Adventure, as introduced in the trailer below.

 

Cast Reveal

 

 

A freshly cracked piece of key art was also released:

 

 

 

RELATED: Netflix Reveals Theme Song Performer for Gudetama: An Eggcellent Adventure

 

 

Netflix, who'll be streaming Gudetama: An Eggcellent Adventure worldwide from December 13, describes the series as such:

 

A lethargic, empathetic road movie about finding one’s parents — for everyone who just wants to laze about!
Having resigned itself to the fact that it will just end up on someone’s plate, Gudetama just wants to be lazy all the time. But, swept up by the go-getting, overbearing chick Shakipiyo, it leaves the refrigerator and heads out into the world. Together, these polar opposites go on an adventure to find their mother!

 

Source: Netfix Japan on Twitter (1,2)

 

 

Der shy man behind @Shymander, Liam is a timezone-fluid Aussie with a distinct fondness for anime, Eurovision and creating odd stats projects despite hating math.

heading: Crunchyroll to Bring More Subs and Hindi Dubs to Anime Fans in India
sub_heading: Crunchyroll will also be attending Comic Con India events for the first time
metadata: Anime fans in India have a lot to look forward to as Crunchyroll reveals rollout plans for subs and dubs of hit series both in Hindi and Indian English subs and dubs. In addition to subt
author: Guest Author
tags: crunchyroll, india, hindi dubs, demon slayer: kimetsu no yaiba, mobile suit gundam: the witch from mercury
body_content:
Anime fans in India have a lot to look forward to as Crunchyroll reveals rollout plans for subs and dubs of hit series both in Hindi and Indian English subs and dubs. In addition to subtitled October season titles, Crunchyroll announced weekly dubbed episode drops for shows like Demon Slayer: Kimetsu no Yaiba Entertainment District Arc and Darling in the FRANXX, so let's take a closer look at what's on the way in the future.

 

RELATED: Crunchyroll Announces Hindi Dubs for Ranking of Kings, My Dress-Up Darling

 

Weekly episodic drops are on the way for the following titles, dubbed in Hindi and Indian English: Demon Slayer Kimetsu no Yaiba Mugen Train, Demon Slayer Kimetsu no Yaiba Entertainment District Arc, Darling in the FRANXX and Fire Force.

 

Fans will also be able to catch the first season of the RADIANT anime with a Hindi dub along with continuing Hindi dubbed episodes of Ranking of Kings.

 

Additional titles with Hindi or Indian English dubs that are on the way over the next three months include Akebi's Sailor Uniform, Tokyo 24th Ward, Trapped in a Dating Sim: The World of Otome Games is Tough for Mobs and Miss KUROITSU from the Monster Development Department.

 

As for the ongoing October season, All Saints Street, Raven of the Inner Palace, BOCCHI THE ROCK!, Do It Yourself!!, Legend of Mana -The Teardrop Crystal-, Mobile Suit Gundam: The Witch from Mercury and Berserk: The Golden Age Arc - Memorial Edition - are among the shows subtitled in English and available now.

 

Additional English content—both subbed and dubbed—from Crunchyroll's extensive library will be made available to Indian subscribers on the first and third Wednesday of each month starting in November, so look for more soon!

 

Beyond all the new show drops, Crunchyroll will be attending Comic Con India for the first time, with presence in each of its locations: Bengaluru (November 19-20), Delhi (December 9-11) and Mumbai (February 11-12).

heading: FEATURE: Ranking Kuroko’s Basketball: Generation of Miracles This NBA Season
sub_heading: The five fiercest junior high ballers… and Tetsuya
metadata: Every once in a while in the world of basketball something truly frightening occurs; an intersection of talent so rare that it changes the landscape of the sport. Superteams of this cali
author: Tony Cocking
tags: feature, kuroko's basketball, generation of miracles, sports anime, basketball
body_content:
Every once in a while in the world of basketball something truly frightening occurs; an intersection of talent so rare that it changes the landscape of the sport. Superteams of this caliber assemble with such scarcity that their legend is spoken of in hushed whispers for years to come. For the junior high circuit of Tokyo, that superteam was Teiko.

 

The Generation of Miracles of Kuroko’s Basketball was a lineup of prodigious ballers capable of impossible feats of athleticism. Captained by their stone-faced point guard, Seijuro Akashi, the starting five of Teiko could blow out opponents in any number of ways. The only thing lacking was a unified love for the game, and upon graduation, they would all go their separate ways, destined to meet again as bitter rivals. Their high school duels would become just as legendary, with each acting as their team’s respective star player, but who among them could truly be considered the king of the court? It’s time to put them to the test and determine who among the Generation of Miracles is the greatest baller of them all.

 

NOTE: Due to severe misconduct, former Teiko forward Shogo Haizaki will not be acknowledged in this listing in any way, shape, or form. His tenure had ended in disgrace before the Generation of Miracles had truly formed, and more importantly, he stole my lunch one time.

 

6. Tetsuya Kuroko

 

Strength: I’m really not sure.

Weakness: I didn’t even know this dude existed.

 

We start our rankings somewhat awkwardly by having to acknowledge the rumor that Teiko had a ‘phantom sixth member’ who allegedly played alongside the Generation of Miracles. According to Ryota Kise and Atsushi Murasakibarra, his name is ‘Kurokocchi’ or ‘Kuro-chin’ or something. Honestly, they’re probably just pulling my leg.

 

RELATED: Kuroko's Basketball Anime Heads to the Court in GRANRODEO's 10th Anniversary Music Video

 

I’m not fond of dealing in gossip, but word on the street is that this enigmatic sixth man was adept at dealing lightning-quick passes that amplified the skills of anyone he played with. He was otherwise a non-factor as an offensive option, and overall, an unspectacular young man who would go largely unnoticed by his peers. With that in mind, we cannot anoint this ‘Kuroko’ fellow as anything more than a footnote in the legend of Teiko. That being said, if this "phantom" business is true, this Kuroko person could be a fantastic shadow to someone’s light.

 

5. Shintaro Midorima

 

Strength: Threes so deep they discovered Atlantis.

Weakness: Superstitious, stubborn, and unpleasant.

 

The former Teiko vice-captain’s defining trait is his ability to launch three-point rainbows from literally anywhere on the court. Leaving him open is a concession that you would like to lose the game badly, but he is also fast and shifty enough to lose would-be defenders. Midorima is able to commence his shot before the ball has even landed in his hands. It’s quite a sight to see, and I fear that if any of us were to attempt this in real life we would just end up embarrassed.

 

RELATED: Players Gather in THE FIRST SLAM DUNK Anime Movie Visual

 

Despite this, his particular skill requires more setup from his teammates than the other Teiko alumni. Shutting down the other players can spell disaster for this verdant sharpshooter, and though he can create for himself to a degree, he is the only member of the Generation of Miracles not known to have ever dunked or entered "The Zone."

 

Even if Midorima were to dunk, he’d probably suck all the fun out of it somehow.

 

4. Atsushi Murasakibara

 

Strength: Intimidating physical presence.

Weakness: Infuriating mental presence.

 

Atsushi Murasakibara's towering frame gives the impression that he would be an unstoppable force. Kise has gone so far as to declare that “he may be the most naturally talented of the five of us.” In one game during his tenure with Teiko, he scored 100 points!

 

Alas, I don’t hand out trophies for talent as Murasakibara’s mercurial temperament will dictate whether he’ll make any effort whatsoever. He might elect to only play defense or request he be subbed out of the game entirely. If apathy were a person, it wouldn’t even be him, because he wouldn’t bother turning up to prove that point. He's basically the antithesis of Midorima. If they were to swap bodies, Murasakibara would be a distant fifth in this ranking — without his physical blessings he would be nothing more than an enthusiasm sinkhole.

 

3. Ryota Kise

 

Strength: Versatile and capable of almost anything.

Weakness: Restricted stamina, arguably too pretty for basketball.

 

If I was the general manager of a professional basketball team and I possessed the first overall draft pick, I would very likely select Ryota Kise over his contemporaries.

 

Kise's an enthusiastic sweetheart still refining his game. Don’t make the critical mistake of teaching him the ropes, however, as he will use those ropes to tie you in knots. Kise is an observant player who repurposes other people’s abilities for his own, emulating them so well that he's actually able to iron out their flaws and refine them into perfect techniques. His potential is nigh limitless, and someday he could very well become the greatest basketball player the world has ever seen.

 

The only things holding him back at the moment are a comparative lack of experience and the fact that pulling off his Perfect Copy exhausts a great deal of energy. Impressive as it may be, it’s not dependable for long stretches of gameplay. Additionally, Kise has not yet shown the capacity to be a leader for his squad, humbly deferring to others. This is perhaps to his own detriment, but it does, at the very least, earn him valuable cute points.

 

2. Seijuro Akashi

 

Strength: HE SEES ALL.

Weakness: He suffers the duality of man.

 

Seijuro Akashi has all the makings of a final boss. At first glance, he is an unassuming playmaker and floor general, but his hypnotic Emperor Eye renders opponents reeling in his path.

 

Trying to quantify where he ranks on this list is a tricky bit of business. On skill or physical acumen alone he would lose badly to any of the other members of the Generation of Miracles. The thing that makes him so unstoppable, most fittingly, is his power to stop others. Beyond that, he simultaneously motivates and manipulates his teammates, driving them to perform at their best. It’s no surprise that he made Teiko the fearsome beasts that they were as even the most defiant of personalities would bend to his will.

 

RELATED: Kuroko and Kagami Take a Timeout in Kuroko's Basketball 10th Anniversary Teaser Anime Visual

 

Why, then, does this master strategist fall short of the top spot? It comes down to a lack of resilience. His pride is absolute and he has more checks and balances to control the tempo of a single game than most would plan in a season. Should someone bypass all of these master plans, he can become dumbstruck, even frantic.

 

Don’t tell him I said that. This kid scares me.

 

1. Daiki Aomine

 

Strength: Practically perfect in every aspect.

Weakness: Poor cooperation, cryptic onomatopoeias.

 

Aomine is a human cheat code, ready to obliterate entire opponent lineups by himself with an endless array of moves. If you somehow found yourself in the perfect position to block his shot he’d simply contort in midair to score around you. As he once said, “the only one who can beat me, is me,” which is a bit ironic when he ends up losing to Taiga Kagami — who basically is Aomine but redder.

 

RELATED: Which Sports Anime Should You Watch Next?

 

The menacing power forward is an isolation-heavy ace player, bullying defenders with his superior physicality. His capability to access the vaunted "Zone" is perhaps the most unsurprising as such a concept seems tailor-made for someone of his talent threshold. His style is unorthodox and his will is oppressive, and though playing on the same team as him may reduce you to a mere spectator, the results are indisputable. 

 

 

The championship has been decided and the confetti is littered across the court… But what do you think? Is it foolhardy to discount Akashi’s overwhelming dominance? Should Midorima or Murasakibara be given more credit? Do you know who this “Kuroko” character actually is? Let us know in the comments!

heading: Kuroko and Kagami Take a Timeout in Kuroko's Basketball 10th Anniversary Teaser Anime Visual
sub_heading: Production I.G. will produce a new anime music based on the franchise this year
metadata: It may have been 10 years since the game started, but Seirin High's Kuroko and Kagami still have game – though they're taking a little bit of a break from said game in the
author: Daryl Harding
tags: kuroko's basketball, kuroko no basuke, production ig, granrodeo, weekly shonen jump, tadatoshi fujimaki
body_content:
It may have been 10 years since the game started, but Seirin High's Kuroko and Kagami still have game – though they're taking a little bit of a break from said game in the new 10th Anniversary teaser anime visual for Kuroko's Basketball.

 

The anime visual comes hot off the heels of the announcement of a brand new anime music video produced by Production I.G. featuring a brand new song by GRANRODEO feat. Kensho Ono, who are known for performing many of the TV anime themes.

 

 

 

 

 

10th-anniversary logo featuring Tetsuya #2

 

Alongside the music video, Kuroko's Basketball will also be getting an exhibition in April in Tokyo and June in Osaka called "Kuroko's Basketball ANIMATION GALLERY ~ 10 Years of Miracles ~", as well as an event in July in Tokyo, and September at Osaka's Hirakata Park called the "Kuroko's Basketball 10th-Anniversary PARTY!"

 

The Kuroko's Basketball TV anime began in April 2012 and ended in June 2015, with the series getting a film, Kuroko's Basketball The Movie LAST GAME on March 18, 2017. All the Kuroko anime is streaming subbed on Crunchyroll and dubbed on Netflix. Crunchyroll describes the franchise as such:

 

An up-and-coming power player, Taiga Kagami, is just back from America. When he comes to Seirin High School, he meets the super-ordinary boy, Tetsuya Kuroko. Kagami is shocked to find that Kuroko isn't good at basketball, in fact, he's bad! And he's so plain that he's impossible to see. But Kuroko's plainness lets him pass the ball around without the other team noticing him, and he's none other than the sixth member of the Miracle Generation.

 

Source: Kuroko's Basketball on Twitter

 

----

Daryl Harding is a Japan Correspondent for Crunchyroll News. He also runs a YouTube channel about Japan stuff called TheDoctorDazza, tweets at @DoctorDazza, and posts photos of his travels on Instagram.

heading: Variety: Hollywood Live-Action Adaptation Of Your Name Anime Film Lands New Director
sub_heading: Paramount Pictures to distribute film outside of Japan with film undergoing rewrite
metadata: Hollywood trade newswire Variety has confirmed that the director of the animated film Raya and the Last Dragon in Carlos López Estrada has now signed onto the Hollywod live-a
author: Humberto Saabedra
tags: your name, hollywood, live-action, makoto shinkai
body_content:
Hollywood trade newswire Variety has confirmed that the director of the animated film Raya and the Last Dragon in Carlos López Estrada has now signed onto the Hollywod live-action adaptation of the Japanese anime film Your Name as its new director at the insistence of the film's production committee. He officially replaces the film's previously announced director in Marc Webb, first announced in 2019 to great fanfare.

 

The adaptation is being jointly produced by Japan's Toho and J.J. Abrams' Bad Robot production house with Paramount handling US and international distribution outside Japan. López Estrada has also been tasked with writing a brand new script alongside directing duties as the film continues active development, replacing the film's initial script. 

 

Crunchyroll currently streams Your Name and describes it:

 

Mitsuha and Taki are total strangers living completely different lives. But when Mitsuha makes a wish to leave her mountain town for the bustling city of Tokyo, they become connected in a bizarre way. She dreams she is a boy living in Tokyo while Taki dreams he is a girl from a rural town he’s never visited. What does their newfound connection mean? And how will it bring them together?

 

SOURCE: Variety

heading: Hyouka TV Anime Celebrates 10th Anniversary With Film Concert in Saitama
sub_heading: Performance features theme song performer ChouCho and voice actors Satomi Sato and Daisuke Sakaguchi as guests
metadata: Some quick news for fans of high school mysteries: Hyouka, the TV anime adaptation based on the light novel series by Honobu Yonezawa about a high school classic literature club that dab
author: Paul Chapman
tags: hyouka, honobu yonezawa, kadokawa shoten, light novels, yasuhiro takemoto, kyoto animation, concerts, saitama, january 2023
body_content:
Some quick news for fans of high school mysteries: Hyouka, the TV anime adaptation based on the light novel series by Honobu Yonezawa about a high school classic literature club that dabbles in solving problems, is celebrating its 10th anniversary with a special "film concert" performance in Saitama in January that includes voice actors and a theme song performer as guests.

 

The "Hyouka TV Anime 10th Anniversary Film Concert ~Kamiyama High's Small Recital~" event will be held at the Japan Pavilion Hall A of the Tokorozawa Sakura Town venue in Saitama Prefecture on January 29, 2023 with a daytime performance at 1:45pm and an evening performance at 5:30pm.

 

The concert will be performed by the Kamiyama High Ensemble, and voice actors Satomi Sato (the voice of Eru Chitanda) and Daisuke Sakaguchi (the voice of Satoshi Fukube) as well as opening theme song performer ChouCho will appear as guests. Tickets range in price from 9900 yen (about $66.59 US) for reserved seating to 13,500 yen (about $90.80 US) for premium seating with a commemorative desktop calendar as a bonus gift.

 

 

RELATED: FEATURE: How Slice-of-Life Anime Complements Other Genres

 

Hyouka is directed by Yasuhiro Takemoto and features animation production by Kyoto Animation. Crunchyroll currently streams the series, and describes the story of it as follows:

 

After disenchanted student Hotaro Oreki joins his school’s Classic Lit Club, he meets Eru Chitanda, a kindhearted and inquisitive girl with boundless curiosity and a knack for getting him caught up in all sorts of trouble.

 

Source: Comic Natalie

 

Copyright notice: © Honobu Yonezawa・Kadokawa Shoten / Kamiyama High School Classic Literature Club OB Association

 

 

---

Paul Chapman is the host of The Greatest Movie EVER! Podcast and GME! Anime Fun Time.

heading: Bondo's Mom, Nyonta Character Designs Shown Off for Me & Roboco TV Anime
sub_heading: The short gag series starts on December 4
metadata: Me & Roboco is throwing its knees into the anime realm in December, introducing anime fans to the wacky antics of the futuristic world where every househo
author: Daryl Harding
tags: me & roboco, weekly shonen jump, akitaro daichi, gallop, december 2022
body_content:
Image via VIZ Media

 

Me & Roboco is throwing its knees into the anime realm in December, introducing anime fans to the wacky antics of the futuristic world where every household has OrderMaids. Ahead of then though, the series revealed some brand new character designs for more of the series' core cast members.

 

Nyonta

 

Meico

 

Bondo's Mom

 

Ruri

 

RELATED: Comedy Anime Me & Roboco Outputs Designs for Five Main Characters

 

Me & Roboco is being directed by Akitaro Daichi (Kamisama Kiss) with Michihira Sato in the role as assistant director at Studio Gallop. Sayuri Ooba writes the series composition with animated character designs by Yuko Ebara. The series is set to premiere on December 4 in Japan in a five-minute timeslot. Viz Media, who releases the official English edition of Shuhei Miyazaki's manga, describes the first volume as such:

 

Now that Bondo has his very own OrderMaid, it’s time to show her off to his friends. But will they be able to handle Roboco? And what exactly is the secret behind this special robot?!

 

Source: Comic Natalie

 

---- 

Daryl Harding is a Senior Japan Correspondent for Crunchyroll News. He also runs a YouTube channel about Japan stuff called TheDoctorDazza, tweets at @DoctorDazza, and posts photos of his travels on Instagram.

heading: Kuroko's Basketball Anime Heads to the Court in GRANRODEO's 10th Anniversary Music Video
sub_heading: Production I.G. produced the new anime music
metadata: After being announced back in January, the 10th-anniversary music video to celebrate the first broadcast of the Kuroko's Basketball TV anime was released today, featuring a
author: Daryl Harding
tags: tags kuroko's basketball, kuroko no basuke, production ig, granrodeo, weekly shonen jump, tadatoshi fujimaki
body_content:
After being announced back in January, the 10th-anniversary music video to celebrate the first broadcast of the Kuroko's Basketball TV anime was released today, featuring all the Generation of Miracles (plus Kagami) going about their daily school life in new animation produced at Production I.G from the original series director and storyboarder Shunsuke Tada. 

 

 

The music video features the single "Zero Step" from GRANRODEO, who performed many of the theme songs for the Kuroko's Basketball franchise and features vocals from Kensho Ono, who voiced the titular Tetsuya Kuroko in the series.

 

RELATED: Kuroko's Basketball TV Anime Gets Year-Long 10th Anniversary Celebrations

 

The video was released as part of the year-long celebrations for the Kuroko's Basketball franchise, which have included a new visual as well as events sprinkled throughout the year across Japan.

 

The Kuroko's Basketball TV anime began in April 2012 and ended in June 2015, with the series getting a film, Kuroko's Basketball The Movie LAST GAME on March 18, 2017. All the Kuroko anime is streaming subbed on Crunchyroll and dubbed on Netflix. Crunchyroll describes the franchise as such:

 

An up-and-coming power player, Taiga Kagami, is just back from America. When he comes to Seirin High School, he meets the super-ordinary boy, Tetsuya Kuroko. Kagami is shocked to find that Kuroko isn't good at basketball, in fact, he's bad! And he's so plain that he's impossible to see. But Kuroko's plainness lets him pass the ball around without the other team noticing him, and he's none other than the sixth member of the Miracle Generation.

 

Source: Comic Natalie

 

----

Daryl Harding is a Japan Correspondent for Crunchyroll News. He also runs a YouTube channel about Japan stuff called TheDoctorDazza, tweets at @DoctorDazza, and posts photos of his travels on Instagram.

heading: Kitsune Worries About Her Ears in Gorgeous Dongitsune Nissin Anime Ad
sub_heading: Saori Hayami plays the role of the jealous fox girl
metadata: Only a month after launching its Autumn campaign, Nissin Foods is back with yet another absolutely breathtaking anime commercial featuring their Dongitsune character who is yet again
author: Daryl Harding
tags: nissin foods, donbei, kitsune udon, commercial, taishi morii
body_content:
Only a month after launching its Autumn campaign, Nissin Foods is back with yet another absolutely breathtaking anime commercial featuring their Dongitsune character who is yet again jealous over a bowl of instant donbei. This month's animated commercial sees character designs from manga artist Taishi Mori, who is best known for creating the Radiation House series.

 

 

The story of this animated adventure is set in Japan's Taisho period, where Dongitsune, who is voiced by Saori Hayami (Yor Forger in SPY x FAMILY), appears in front of a glasses-wearing man, voiced by Kensho Ono (Tetsuya Kuroko in Kuroko's Basketball), who is eating some donbei. While Nissin Foods does sell as "kitsune donbei," the man explains that no, it is actually the tempura version that he is eating. Dongitsune is of course, never happy about this.

 

RELATED: Autumn is Mysterious in "Dongitsune" Animated TV CM for Nissin Foods

 

More anime commercials for Nissin Foods' donbei are set to be released in the future, and honestly, these bite-sized animated stories are just a treat to snack on. 

 

Source: Comic Natalie

 

---- 

Daryl Harding is a Senior Japan Correspondent for Crunchyroll News. He also runs a YouTube channel about Japan stuff called TheDoctorDazza, tweets at @DoctorDazza, and posts photos of his travels on Instagram.

heading: Autumn is Mysterious in "Dongitsune" Animated TV CM for Nissin Foods
sub_heading: 30 second TV spot features character designs by manga artist Eisaku Kubonouchi
metadata: Autumn is a time for mysterious meetings in a new animated TV commercial series entitled Dongitsune Season 2 Autumn Edition", which features a cute fox-spirit girl to promote
author: Paul Chapman
tags: nissin foods, nissin no donbei, kitsune udon, tv commercial, weird promotions, eisaku kubonouchi, september 2022
body_content:
Autumn is a time for mysterious meetings in a new animated TV commercial series entitled "Dongitsune Season 2 Autumn Edition", which features a cute fox-spirit girl to promote Nissin Foods' "Nissin no Donbei" line of instant kitsune udon noodle dishes. The 30 second TV spot (below) features character designs by manga author Eisaku Kubonouchi, who also worked on the "HUNGRY DAYS" series for Nissin Cup Noodles.

 

 

RELATED: Laid-Back Camp Collaborates with Cup Noodle Curry

 

In the commercial, a bespectacled youth (voiced by Kikunosuke Toya) is eating kitsune udon when Dongitsune (voiced by An Ogawa) appears. They attend an autumn festival together, but afterwards the mysterious fox-spirit girl vanishes...

 

A full-length version of the TV commercial will begin broadcasting on TV stations throughout Japan on September 28, 2022.

 

Source: Anime! Anime!

 

Copyright notice: Copyright © NISSIN FOODS HOLDINGS CO.,LTD. All Rights Reserved.

 

 

---

Paul Chapman is the host of The Greatest Movie EVER! Podcast and GME! Anime Fun Time.

heading: Find the Devil Hunters During Chainsaw Man GPS Rally
sub_heading: Plus, grab real-world goods at the connected pop-up shop and Twitter campaign
metadata: Do you have what it takes to be a Devil Hunter? A new GPS game is testing hopefuls in exchange for prizes!
author: Kara Dennison
tags: chainsaw man, tatsuki fujimoto, mappa, shueisha, pop-up shop
body_content:
Do you have what it takes to be a Devil Hunter? A new GPS game is testing hopefuls in exchange for prizes!

 

Titled Chainsaw Man Public Safety Anti-Magic Division 4 Devil Hunter Recruitment ~Search for the Devil Hunters GPS Rally~, the event will take place across five train stations in Tokyo, ending at a pop-up shop in Sunshine City ALTA. Participants can download a special app and collect digital "stamps" at all six locations, turning them in at the end for event art.

 

 

RELATED: Monster Strike x Chainsaw Man Collab Results in Devilishly Fun Character Art

 

The pop-up shop also offer posters, pillows, and more. Some of these prizes will also be offered during a follow and retweet campaign being held by the event's official Twitter account.

 

 

RELATED: Chainsaw Man Manga Adds 2 Million Copies to Its Total Run Since Anime Began

 

The Chainsaw Man GPS rally and pop-up shop will be held November 1-28, with an in-store lottery taking place November 11 where fans can play for even more prizes.

 

© Tatsuki Fujimoto/Shueisha/MAPPA

 

Source: Comic Natalie

 

Watch Chainsaw Man on Crunchyroll!

 

 

------

Kara Dennison is an author of fiction and non-fiction, avid tabletop gamer, and regular Otaku USA Magazine features writer. Follow her on Twitter @RubyCosmos, and read more at KaraDennison.com.

heading: New Chainsaw Man TV Anime Figure Recreates Power’s Dominant Toilet-Sitting Stance
sub_heading: Chainsaw Man streams weekly here on Crunchyroll
metadata: Power made a mightily persuasive point while perched on the Hayakawa toilet in the latest episode of the Chainsaw Man TV anime, and Shibuya Scramble Figure has announced
author: Daryl Harding
tags: chainsaw man, tatsuki fujimoto, weekly shonen jump, mappa, october 2022, figure, shibuya scramble figure
body_content:
Power made a mightily persuasive point while perched on the Hayakawa toilet in the latest episode of the Chainsaw Man TV anime, and Shibuya Scramble Figure has announced today that the premium figure company have recreated the figure of Power provoking to take home. 

 

 

 

 

 

The 1/7th scale Power figure comes in at around 18cm tall with focus given to the details of Power’s jagged teeth, the looseness of her clothes and the delicate position of her hand and fingers. The Hayakawa toilet has also been completely recreated down to the last drop of detail. Pre-orders for the figure have gone online at Shibuya Scramble Figure’s website for a powerful 29,920 yen (US$204) and is set to ship out in September 2023.

 

RELATED: Chainsaw Man Anime Releases Fourth Ending Video Featuring TOOBOE

 

For those who pre-order through Shibuya Scramble Figure's website or Amazon's Japanese website, an adorable Meowy will also come with Power, giving you a double dose of troubl– cuteness.

 

 

Chainsaw Man premiered on Japanese TV on October 11, with Crunchyroll streaming the anime as it airs in North America, Central America, South America, Europe, Africa, Oceania, the Middle East and CIS. The series is described as such:

 

Denji is a teenage boy living with a Chainsaw Devil named Pochita. Due to the debt his father left behind, he has been living a rock-bottom life while repaying his debt by harvesting devil corpses with Pochita.
 

One day, Denji is betrayed and killed. As his consciousness fades, he makes a contract with Pochita and gets revived as "Chainsaw Man" — a man with a devil's heart. 

 

Source: Mantan Web

 

---- 

Daryl Harding is a Senior Japan Correspondent for Crunchyroll News. He also runs a YouTube channel about Japan stuff called TheDoctorDazza, tweets at @DoctorDazza, and posts photos of his travels on Instagram.

heading: FEATURE: Aki’s Morning Routine is One of My Favorite Chainsaw Man Moments So Far
sub_heading: Sometimes the best things in life are drinking coffee and reading the paper
metadata: NOTE: The following article contains spoilers for the fourth episode of the Chainsaw Man anime. Chainsaw Man has settled into my Tuesday evening schedule. After work, I make
author: Briana Lawrence
tags: chainsaw man, aki, denji, power, anime
body_content:
NOTE: The following article contains spoilers for the fourth episode of the Chainsaw Man anime.

 

Chainsaw Man has settled into my Tuesday evening schedule. After work, I make myself comfortable in the living room and tune in to see what Denji’s up to. I’m usually eating dinner or having a drink, my cats curled up on the couch, and my wife telling me how much she’s enjoying the series and trying REAL HARD to not grab the manga and binge-read it in one sitting (I predict she’s going to fail). It’s a consistent routine I’ve got going and one I’ve come to appreciate. 

 

To my surprise, the fourth episode of this balls-to-the-wall anime decided to demonstrate how nice it is to have a part of your day that’s solely yours and/or shared with someone who’s adopted the same vibe. It didn’t gloss over it, either. The episode legitimately quiets down for a few minutes just to show a well-animated, mundane moment in Aki’s day. 

 

RELATED: Everything You Need to Know Before Watching Chainsaw Man

 

Honestly? It’s a major highlight, not just in the episode but in the series itself so far.   

 

Chainsaw Man is full of gloriously bloody action, frightening creature designs and protagonists you’d want to keep on a leash when walking around with them because you know they’re gonna get into trouble. The beginning of the fourth episode is a reminder of the mayhem of the series. Just when you think Denji’s won, another devil appears to pick up where the last one left off. Denji can’t turn into the titular character, too low on blood from the last battle. He keeps fighting, though, and holds his own for as long as he can. Fortunately, Aki shows up and ends things with a single command.

 

 

From there we get a bit of quiet — but not really. Denji’s recovering, but the conversation is serious. Power set him up to be killed by the Bat Devil. Aki knows that Denji’s covering for her for some reason, and he knows that he has to tell Makima something about what happened. Things are worked out eventually, leading to Aki waking up the next day and going about his business.

 

This brings us the scene I referenced earlier. For a couple of minutes we watch Aki get out of bed, wash his face, brush his teeth, make himself a cup of coffee, and go out and read the paper. That’s all that happens. Every part of his morning is animated with just as much care as the anime’s more crucial moments. The colored swirls of Aki’s toothpaste. Him grating his coffee beans before dumping them into a filter and gently pouring in hot water. Him enjoying the morning breeze from his balcony. It’s a complete contrast to what we’ve seen in the series so far and I love it just as much as I love everything else in Chainsaw Man.

 

RELATED: Chainsaw Man Anime Releases Fourth Ending Video Featuring TOOBOE

 

That’s not to say we haven’t gotten any downtime with these characters, there’s just always something else going on. Makima embraces Denji after he slaughters a horde of zombies, but that comes with her making a deal with him. Denji getting to finally enjoy toast and jam is loud, messy and paired with Aki’s annoyed scowl. Power enjoying time with Meowy involves massacring animals for food and the Bat Devil snatching her cat away. There hasn’t been much of anything that just lets a character BE... until now.

 

 

Having something that’s regular and yours is important. It’s not just Aki we see this with. This scene also shows Denji waking up and going about his day less chaotically than when he first got to Aki’s place. The calm morning has obviously had an effect on him. I dare say Denji’s gotten comfortable — something he sorely needs. 

 

As Aki does laundry and vacuums, Denji simply eats his toast. The bread isn’t as haphazard as it was in Episode 2, the table and utensils are clean and Denji is just... quiet. The two are also civil toward each other, with Aki cutting up the ingredients to make curry for lunch. It’s nice to see the two getting along, but it’s also a genuinely relatable moment. After all the heart-pounding action in your life, you really do want to drink coffee, read the paper and clean your place. I’ve lost count of the number of times I’ve felt pure bliss from putting groceries away or seeing my favorite bubble bath brand on sale. 

 

RELATED: Chainsaw Man Anime Hype Hits Celebrities, Xbox and… the US Consumer Product Safety Commission?

 

This all goes out the window when Power shows up, providing a comical level of disorganization that makes you feel for Aki. That being said, it’s interesting to see Denji being the voice of reason in regard to taking care of the house. Before, it had been Aki telling him not to choose violence, but now Aki gets to watch as Denji tells Power to respect vegetables and flush the toilet. I get the feeling the tranquility of Aki’s apartment will do some good if its effect on Denji is any indication. 

 

I wasn’t expecting this kind of character interaction in a series where a guy can have a chainsaw erupt from his forehead, but in an anime so wild, I’m here for the tranquil moments.  

 

 

 

 

Briana Lawrence is the Senior EN Features Editor here at Crunchyroll. When she’s not writing she’s taking care of her three butthead cats and playing Hades for the 100th time. You can check out her writings and her book series over at her website and give her a shout-over on Twitter.

heading: YOASOBI's Mobile Suit Gundam: The Witch from Mercury Opening Theme MV Reaches 10 Million Views
sub_heading: The latest Gundam TV series is simulcast on Crunchyroll
metadata: The official Twitter for Japanese music duo YOASOBI announced that the music video for their latest song "Shukufuku" (The Blessing) had reached 10 million views only in one month.
author: Mikikazu Komatsu
tags: yoasobi, mv, mobile suit gundam: the witch from mercury, fall 2022
body_content:
The official Twitter for Japanese music duo YOASOBI announced that the music video for their latest song "Shukufuku" (The Blessing) had reached 10 million views only in one month.

 

RELATED: Rookie Singer Shiyui Posts Mobile Suit Gundam: The Witch from Mercury Ending Theme MV

 

The song was digitally released on October 1 and has been featured as the opening theme for the TV anime Mobile Suit Gundam: The Witch from Mercury. As their second CD single following "Kaibutsu/Yasashii Suisei" (TV anime BEASTARS theme songs) in March 2021, the CD single of "Shukufuku" is set to be released in Japan on November 9, 2022.

 

The single also includes the title song's English version, "The Blessing," and its short audio sample is previewed in the Twitter post below:

heading: Spy Classroom TV Anime Makes a Stroke of Genius with Monika Character Visual, Trailer
sub_heading: Studio feel. produces action-comedy anime series
metadata: Every Friday is a treat for fans looking forward to the upcoming Spy Classroom anime, which enters the fourth round of its regular mission to introduce each of its operatives with a snaz
author: Liam Dempsey
tags: spy classroom, aoi yuki, feel., keiichiro kawaguchi, january 2023
body_content:
Every Friday is a treat for fans looking forward to the upcoming Spy Classroom anime, which enters the fourth round of its regular mission to introduce each of its operatives with a snazzy character visual and trailer, leading the action-comedy anime's official Twitter account to enlist Monika, voiced by Aoi Yuki (Tanya in Saga of Tanya the Evil), this week.

 

Monika Character Visual

 

Monika Character Trailer

 

 

RELATED: Spy Classroom TV Anime Becomes a Crowd with Sibylla Character Visual, Trailer

 

 

Keiichiro Kawaguchi (Higurashi: When They Cry - GOU) is directing the adaptation at studio feel. (Remake Our Life!), with series composition by Shinichi Inozume (Platinum End) and character designs by Sumie Kinoshita (Idoly Pride). Yuichiro Umehara (Kimura in Heaven's Design Team) will take on the identity of elite spy Klaus, with Sora Amamiya (Chizuru in Rent-a-Girlfriend) by his side as Lily, one of several trainees with no experience in espionage.


Yen Press, who publishes the light novels' official English version, describes the series as such:


INTELLIGENCE IS THE MOST DANGEROUS WEAPON


Following a devastating military conflict, countries fight their wars in the shadows. One unusual spy, Klaus, has never failed on the job despite his quirks, and he is building a team to take on an Impossible Mission—one with over a 90 percent chance of failure. However, his chosen members are all washouts with no practical experience. They’ll have to use every trick in the book (and some that aren’t) to prove they’re up to the task!

 

Spy Classroom is scheduled to begin airing in January 2023.

 

Source: Official Twitter

 

 

Der shy man behind @Shymander, Liam is a timezone-fluid Aussie with a distinct fondness for anime, Eurovision and creating odd stats projects despite hating math.

heading: KanColle Season 2: Let's Meet at Sea TV Anime Celebrates Today's Premiere With New Visual
sub_heading: Crunchyroll will be streaming the series as it airs in Japan
metadata: To celebrate the premiere of the first episode of KanColle Season 2: Let's Meet at Sea today, KADOKAWA released a brand new visual for the series showing the battle-ready
author: Daryl Harding
tags: kantai collection, kancolle, fall 2022, engi, kadokawa games, kazuya miura, november 2022
body_content:
To celebrate the premiere of the first episode of KanColle Season 2: Let's Meet at Sea today, KADOKAWA released a brand new visual for the series showing the battle-ready girls treading water. The TV anime begins tonight on Japanese TV with Crunchyroll set to stream the series shortly after.

 

 

RELATED: KanColle: ITSUKA ANO UMI DE Anime Onboards Theme Song Artist with New Trailer

 

KanColle Season 2: Let's Meet at Sea is set in a different continuity than that of the original KanColle series and film, along with having a new staff, a new studio they work at and new voice actors. The series is directed by Kazuya Miura and features animation production by Engi. The show premieres on November 3, with Crunchyroll streaming the series and will run for eight episodes.

 

Crunchyroll currently streams the 2015 KanColle TV anime and describes the story of the series as such:

 

Set in a world where humanity has lost control of the oceans to the “deep sea fleet,” the only hope to counter this threat are the Kanmusu, a group of girls who possess the spirit of Japanese warships. The story revolves around Fubuki, a destroyer who comes to the Chinjufu base to train with other Kanmusu. Watch as their stories unfold!

 

Source: Press Release

 

---- 

Daryl Harding is a Senior Japan Correspondent for Crunchyroll News. He also runs a YouTube channel about Japan stuff called TheDoctorDazza, tweets at @DoctorDazza, and posts photos of his travels on Instagram.

heading: Mobile Suit Gundam: The Witch from Mercury TV Anime Gets Recap Episode on November 13
sub_heading: Crunchyroll streams the latest Gundam series as it airs in Japan
metadata: School will be taking a break for Mobile Suit Gundam: The Witch from Mercury on November 13 as the series is set to air a recap of the first six episodes of the series, giving fans time
author: Daryl Harding
tags: gundam, mobile suit gundam: the witch from mercury, chuatury panlunch, sunrise
body_content:
School will be taking a break for Mobile Suit Gundam: The Witch from Mercury on November 13 as the series is set to air a recap of the first six episodes of the series, giving fans time to review the mecha coursework before the seventh episode airs. 

 

 

11月13日(日)午後5時～
第1～6話までを一挙に振り返る 「#水星の魔女 スペシャル特番」のTV放送決定！

さらに午後5時30分～#市ノ瀬加那 さん #Lynn さん #マフィア梶田 さんによる「第1クール前半戦振り返りSP」をガンダムチャンネルでプレミア公開！

▼番組詳細https://t.co/4AUVfQFRtP#G_Witch

— 機動戦士ガンダム 水星の魔女 (@G_Witch_M) November 1, 2022

 

 

The recap episode will air in the same time slot The Witch from Mercury as usually airs on Japanese TV at 5:00 PM on Sunday, November 13. The recap will be followed by a talk at 5:30 PM featuring Suletta Mercury’s voice actor Kana Ichinose, Miorine Rembran’s voice actor Lynn and hosted by writer and talent Mafia Kajita. 

 

Both the recap and the talk will be uploaded one after another on the GUNDAM Info YouTube channel as well as stream in other places the series streams.

 

RELATED: Mobile Suit Gundam: The Witch from Mercury Anime Art Setting Finally Answers How Chuatury Puts on a Helmet

 

Hiroshi Kobayashi, who directed TRIGGER's original anime KIZNAIVER, is helming Mobile Suit Gundam: The Witch from Mercury at studio Sunrise and Bandai Namco Filmworks alongside Code Geass co-creator Ichiro Okouchi as scriptwriter and series composer. Crunchyroll is currently simulcasting the series and describes it as such:

 

A.S. (Ad Stella) 122― An era when a multitude of corporations have entered space and built a huge economic system. A lone girl from the remote planet Mercury transfers to the Asticassia School of Technology, run by the Beneritt Group which dominates the mobile suit industry. Her name is Suletta Mercury. With a scarlet light burning in her pure heart, this girl walks step by step through a new world.

 

Source: Mobile Suit Gundam: The Witch from Mercury official website

 

---- 

Daryl Harding is a Senior Japan Correspondent for Crunchyroll News. He also runs a YouTube channel about Japan stuff called TheDoctorDazza, tweets at @DoctorDazza, and posts photos of his travels on Instagram.

heading: FEATURE: Exploring the Anime and Literary Inspirations of Mobile Suit Gundam: The Witch from Mercury
sub_heading: Let's explore the parallels between Gundam, Utena, and Shakespeare's The Tempest!
metadata: Have you folks been enjoying Mobile Suit Gundam: The Witch from Mercury? The show has turned out to be one of my favorites of this star-studded season, offering a unique take on the
author: Nick Creamer
tags: mobile suit gundam: the witch from mercury, revolutionary girl utena, the tempest
body_content:
Have you folks been enjoying Mobile Suit Gundam: The Witch from Mercury? The show has turned out to be one of my favorites of this star-studded season, offering a unique take on the Gundam formula, a delightful cast of characters, and of course, some exceedingly satisfying giant robot battles. Personally, my enjoyment has been further enhanced through picking at the show’s apparent textual parallels, as it seems to draw on classics from both anime and literature alike. 

 

 

Through its potential allusions to these classic texts, Mobile Suit Gundam: The Witch from Mercury seems intent on expanding its own thematic scope, drawing on rich existing mythologies to inform its narrative reach. Of course, that effect only really hits home if you can actually see what it’s doing, so let’s explore how Mobile Suit Gundam: The Witch from Mercury seems to draw from both Revolutionary Girl Utena and Shakespeare’s The Tempest.

 

RELATED: 6 More Anime That Will Inspire You To Do It Yourself

 

In broad narrative terms, Mobile Suit Gundam: The Witch from Mercury’s system of a top duelist “Holder” who is automatically betrothed to Miorine, the daughter of the school’s overseer, feels like a direct echo of Revolutionary Girl Utena’s own duelist system and “Rose Bride” prize. Both Miorine and her Revolutionary Girl Utena parallel Anthy begin the series trapped in systems beyond their control, forced to act as prizes and brides for whoever proves their worth in combat. Even the structural system of Suletta fighting off one duelist after another for Miorine’s hand echoes Revolutionary Girl Utena’s episodic foundation.

 

 

In broad narrative terms, Mobile Suit Gundam: The Witch from Mercury’s system of a top duelist “Holder” who is automatically betrothed to Miorine, the daughter of the school’s overseer, feels like a direct echo of Revolutionary Girl Utena’s own duelist system and “Rose Bride” prize. Both Miorine and her Revolutionary Girl Utena parallel Anthy begin the series trapped in systems beyond their control, forced to act as prizes and brides for whoever proves their worth in combat. Even the structural system of Suletta fighting off one duelist after another for Miorine’s hand echoes Revolutionary Girl Utena’s episodic foundation.

 

Beyond these broad narrative strokes, the similarities to Revolutionary Girl Utena continue on the micro level through conceits like Miorine’s greenhouse and tomato garden. Just like Anthy had her private flower garden, Miorine has a private sanctuary that she is fiercely defensive of, a small patch of earth where she can express her own will. Even the temperament of each story’s first top duelist seems similar with Holder Guel effortlessly evoking the violent masculine insecurity of Utena’s Saionji. And I’m frankly not sure which series’ version of Chuchu would be more offended by a comparison to their doppelganger.

 

 

That said, there’s so far been little indication that Mobile Suit Gundam: The Witch from Mercury will follow Revolutionary Girl Utena’s path on a thematic level, diving into specific questions of adolescent identity-forming and gender relations. While the scaffolding is similar, the new Gundam’s active drama seems far more concerned with the economic machinations of its overseers than any sort of intimate social critique. Miorine seemed to affirm this herself in the very first episode, stating that a relationship between her and Suletta would only parse as scandalous to someone from a distant backwater. Still, the possibility is certainly there for future parallels to emerge in time.

 

Speaking of backwaters, while Miorine’s character has largely been framed through touchstones reminiscent of Revolutionary Girl Utena, Suletta’s backstory seems far more indebted to Shakespeare’s The Tempest. This is most glaringly apparent in the choices of Suletta-adjacent character names: the wily sorcerer Prospero has here been shifted to Prospera (maintaining their role as the heroine’s single parent), while the magical spirit Ariel has kept its name largely intact, only shifting one letter to become Suletta’s mobile suit Aerial.

 

 

Beyond their suspiciously similar names, Prospera’s plan also echoes the mechanics of Prospero’s own scheme. Like him, she has been “deposed” from her rightful authority (this time framed in terms of corporations rather than a dukeship) and banished to a remote outpost. From there, both Prospero and Prospera eventually hatch a plan to have their child get close to the child of their nemesis, thereby returning them to their rightful glory. Thrust out into this strange world on her mother’s orders, Suletta’s every word and action seems to echo the baffled, frightened, yet deeply curious words of her Shakespearian counterpart: “oh brave new world, that has such people in it!”

 

Given the absurd density of adjacent names, concepts, and visual touchstones, it seems hard to deny that Okouchi is deliberately evoking the specter of both Revolutionary Girl Utena and The Tempest. But while it’s easy enough to point to areas of commonality, deciphering precisely why he’s making such strong allusions to these secondary texts is a significantly trickier question. So what can we actually draw or decipher from these references?

 

 

First off, one natural consequence of these choices is precisely what we’re doing right now: noticing these textual links, and thereby keeping them in mind when engaging with and analyzing Mobile Suit Gundam: The Witch from Mercury. This is one of the great and most obvious powers of intertextual references; through signifiers like charged name choices or familiar imagery, a thoughtful writer can overlay an entire secondary text’s web of meanings on their own work, creating a more robust thematic conversation through the interactions between them. One work can only contain so many ideas and themes without toppling upon itself; by skillfully employing references to key secondary texts, great fiction can stand on the shoulders of giants, engaging in a conversation that expands beyond its own boundaries.

 

RELATED: Plug in With the Perfect Weekly Watching Schedule

 

 

Additionally, seeing what these texts currently draw from their reference points can also give us some idea of what they might later draw in. In this case, the cruciality of Ariel to The Tempest’s drama, as both a force of magic and a captured soul, could well be echoed through the technological significance of Suletta’s Gundam. Suletta has already been put on trial for the allegedly heretical technology of her Aerial, with both Prospera and Delling clearly squabbling over the power to control this technology. But given we already know this technology was initially designed for medical work, it’s not unreasonable to assume that Aerial’s advances might eventually be offered freely to the people, much like The Tempest’s Ariel was eventually set free.

 

 

Of course, that’s only one of the many interesting conjectures you might draw from Mobile Suit Gundam: Witch from Mercury’s various textual reference points. With two such rich narratives to draw upon, the series’ ability to either embrace referential resonance or complicate and comment on its influences seems practically boundless. Revolutionary Girl Utena’s commentary on youth and identity feel as urgent today as when the show was first released, while The Tempest’s vivid imagery and fantastical narrative make it no surprise that authors through the ages have drawn on its magnetic appeal. Seeing Okouchi embrace such charged points of connection fills me with excitement for what might be yet to come. I’ve been fascinated by Mobile Suit Gundam: The Witch from Mercury’s progress so far, and can’t wait to see what Okouchi has in store for us.

 

 

 

Nick Creamer has been writing about cartoons for too many years now and is always ready to cry about Madoka. You can find more of his work at his blog Wrong Every Time or follow him on Twitter.

heading: nonoc to Perform Opening Theme for Spy Classroom TV Anime
